review_title: Great place to work. I never regretted a second.

cons: Long hours and hard work. They give you a lot but they expect a lot in return.

pros: Google offers on-site physicians, nurses, medical services and health care coverage to keep its employees happy and healthy. Googlers can travel without worries; employees are covered with travel insurance and emergency assistance on both personal and work-related vacations.
cons: Severe disappointment when you realize that Google's reputation for hiring the best and brightest is overblown. You will hear a lot from ex-employees that they felt mediocre and small when surrounded by talented people; I personally have yet to meet those so-called geniuses.

pros: Google was a great place to work with colleagues, and grow my career. I am forever grateful to being lucky enough to be a part of Google.

Strong technical peers - highly educated, exceptionally skilled workforce.

Partners are threatened by size - hard to get data from partners who are afraid we're going to eventually enter their markets.

pros: Working for Google is really great. There are no pressure, you have a certain liberty while you have to maintain a certain level of performance. The atmosphere is stressless.

Pay
Work

review_title: Good work environment, good pay, great perks
job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY

pros: Great Exec Leadership. Fantastic Benefits and Perks.

We have hired tons of folks from other Tech companies into leadership positions and the work culture in Google is no longer "Googly". My advice to anyone who is thinking about joining Google - Do not join for the perks, benefits, work culture. Join if you like the role you are being offered.

pros: This team has the potential to be best they can be but they need to get out of their own way with their egotistical know it all attitude.
cons: This Playstore Production Management team are some of the most pompous, arrogant, juvenile punks I have ever had the misfortune of coming across.  My manager wanted to know when things weren't getting done or were going wrong but when I approached him he would be defensive, accusing, openly blaming and quite snotty and offensive.  This is not the hallmark of anyone cut out to manager other people.  When approaching him with concerns or mistakes, he would twist and turn things around on me that I was blaming other people. And I thought, are you for real?  The female manager was one of the most pompous peacocks that could of used a little ego balancing and reality check. I have news for you, you cannot brow beat, lecture and force feed your sloppy training program and then get on your high horse and lecture people that they are not meeting your expectations. Your training program was like trying to follow an untied off balloon let go in a room. This team is scatterbrained and cocky and comes across as hair on fire, them gets snippy when things go wrong.  Then you will get a email that says "Oh, now I see how this was confusing, my bad!" Well, the damage was already done.  Here's a clue.  Treat your contractors like the qualified, professionals who have brains, skills and common sense that you fail to acknowledge or bother to allow an ounce of autonomy to prove themselves without your nitpicking micromanaging.

job_title: Wardrobe Stylist in New York, NY
pros: You can work remotely and whenever you want "only if" the ques are full and busy which is not usually the case.
cons:
Where do I start? 

In the beginning, all was great! Ques were full and you could make a decent income. As time went on, it's just gotten worse. 

The final nail in the coffin is their new pay model that now pushes commissions and sale incentives. We are no longer stylists. We are now expected to be online sales people! 

There is no rhyme or reason to the new pay model. One minute you are in the Platinum tier making good money and the next you are in a lower tier making a fraction of what you were making before. There is no explanation as to why you are promoted or demoted. It's like you are being punished when you move down a tier because you are no longer meeting their expectations and you will now make less money and have no idea when you may move up again. It's cruel. You are messing with peoples income. It's not right. 

I now work harder and longer hours to make less money despite following the laundry list of their new requirements and examples. We have to send the highest standard messages, send at least 35 items per message and stay with in the users profile requirements. It now takes me at least 10 minutes to send 1 message and that's not only because of their new expectations but also because of all the technical issues. We still get a daily "Bad Request" pop up message when trying to send messages and it interrupts your flow of work. Also, if the user doesn't put in all of their sizes, it limits results and we have to then manually do it which takes even more time. Not to mention Google Shopping is still not working. You have to manually click on each item to get the "+". This all takes more time and becomes so cumbersome. It's ridiculous! You put in so much time and effort for what? To make less $$ now than you did before despite elevating the quality of your work. You feel like a fool. 

Also, they keep on tooting sales and commissions as a good thing. I have yet to see it! It's hard enough to get someone to buy something and if they do, it has to be at least $30, not returned within 2 weeks and you only get a small percentage of the sale. It comes with all these caveats. They are trying to convince us of all the financial gains but that hasn't been the case. 

Lastly, I agree with the review below. The most recent reviews are bogus trying to off set all the negative reviews. You can tell by how generic, vague and overtly positive they are. Just scroll down to page 2 and read all the real reviews.

review_title: Hey Google - check your recruiters. I got hustled.
pros: Everybody I interviewed with was smart, experienced & knowledgeable. The team was great.
cons: I was interviewing with Google and another company at the same time. The other company offered me a contract first. I was honest with the Google recruiters and told them I had an offer on the table. They told me Google would offer me the job b/c my interviews had gone well (I did all of the hangouts, went onsite, etc.). They even asked me what the offer was and assured me that Google would beat it. We discussed exact figures. Things were going great. We communicated multiple times, both on the phone and through email. Each time, they said an offer was coming & repeatedly told me not to sign with anyone, but I'd have to wait a few more days or "next week". Eventually, the other company pulled their offer. I informed the recruiters of this and they said they'd have a verbal offer for me in the coming days. By this time, we are about 2 months into the process. I've heard that it can take up to 3 months to get into Google, so I was complying with everything they said. Another week went by. Late on a Friday afternoon, I get a voicemail (not a phone call) from one of the recruiters. She says there is no offer and she cannot tell me why, but I can call her if I have questions. Of course I do, so I call. She will not pick up. I left her a voicemail, asking for her to get back to me. To this day, she is yet to return my call. Here I am, without a Google offer and I burned a bridge with a great company that actually did want me. Definitely not the experience I was expecting from a leader in our industry. Is this how Google conducts business? Thanks for nothing.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in London, England

review_title: Big company that is a good starting point.

review_title: Likely the last job in my life...

pros:
Still operates much like a start up, with the resources & impact of a large company
Work with awesome people
cons: Too much work - not caused by top down pressure, just by the fact that everyone is super strong & motivated to have an impact, so puts in a lot of hours

review_title: Amazing people, but big company now

-The smartest, most interesting people I've ever worked with
-Amazing perks and benefits - almost too many if that's possible!
-Strength of the Google brand to open doors
cons:
-It's a big company now, which means more politics and slower decision making than 5 years ago
-The commute to Mountain View is killer if you can't afford the costly peninsula
-Work life balance is lacking in some functions

pros: Perks, perks, and perks. I think the benefits package is second to none. The people are great and nice. Plenty of pros, just google it.
cons: It is easy to feel like a cog in a big wheel here. Now that the company is huge, it is harder to find interesting projects that you can own.

pros: Really fun place to work, challenging environment, great people around you and a company with a grand mission, plus the free food - what else do you want?
cons: Sometimes it gets really competitive and since you have highly qualified and ambitious people all around you it can be a bit tough to stand out.

job_title: Product Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Great Company.  The food is amazing. The people are brilliant, and the passion is palpable!
cons: There is a lot of flux at the company (re-orgs on a regular basis), which makes it hard to keep your feet under you.  Working at Google and excelling means either being really flexible and quick, or being inflexible and driving forward with your projects no matter the environment.

pros: Google is a good place to work with free food and great perks. the 20% time to work on own projects is a bit blown though
cons: This company is going the big wigs way. The 20% time to work on own projects is over blown and you really dont get this much time.

pros: good pay if you put in the work you can earn extra money. this way money stacks up. Annual reviews with pay upgrades but no downgrades.
cons: there is really nothing to complain about. Good company. If you put in extra work you get promoted faster and get bonuses.

review_title: Great place to contribute, learn and grow

- great benefits to peace your mind and focus on users

pros: Great people, great food, great benefits

Some people really enjoy that they have 100% mastery of their role from day 1, I found it extremely boring. Difficult process to transfer internally, very strict standards for what roles someone is eligible for based on the internal job code system.

pros: Fun job , really fun , not that much of hard work , friendly employees and friendly boss , easy to talk to no weird people at all
cons: Long hours , sometimes they call too much when on holiday if you are leading teams and stuff life that

pros:

cons: I would rather be living in the south where my family is, but that isn't an option with most companies in this industry. Overall, the cons are very few.

pros:
innovative and creative work culture.

Well paid better than industry standards
cons: You end up working on some internal projects which might be very challenging but do not let you satisfy  the startup spark in you

review_title: came in excited, left very disappointed
job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Mountain View, CA
pros: excellent marketing to it's employees. great benefits, onsite perks
cons: I came in under an acquisition, excited to take on a new role! I found the acquisition team to be unprepared and without answers. My team members were confused about who even their new managers would be. While no one expected handouts, it was hard to find someone even interested in assisting those who came on with temporary roles. It was starting from scratch to find a place in the big Google world.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Smart co workers, lots of perks, solid reliable infrastructure, great work life balance and continuing education. You learn a lot of best practices. The researchers are world class and you get to work on the bleeding edge of technology
cons: Too large one can get lost in the megaplex. At higher levels it can get more and more political. Not much use of open source infrastructure beyond Linux

pros: By and large the quality of colleagues is incredible and is the single largest reason I have remained with the company. The culture respects work / life balance if you are in the right team and the room to grow or move within the company is extensive.
cons: Becoming bigger and more unwieldy and the layer of consultant management just below or at executive level and reducing the scope for innovation

review_title: Google program manager work review. It is truely the best company to work for, ever!! Regret leaving my first job!

cons: big  company, need to prove yourself to succeed, too much ownership so it's bad if you are used to being told what to do, how to do things rather than finding your way on your own.

pros:
Smart coworkers
Unlimited resources to get results
Ability to work on special projects to make an impact on teams
Best place to learn and grow
cons:
Long Hours 60+/wk
No upward mobility in recruiting
High turnover due to contracting sourcers and letting them go after 1 year regardless of performance

pros:
Autonomy in all we do: supplier selection, system design strategy, scheduling, networking
Cross-functional teams and collaboration with outstanding peers
Stock, perks, campus amenities
cons:
Getting more corporate all the time
More and more "fruit company" defectors bringing the 24/7 cut throat culture that they claim to be escaping from
Mountain View and Bay Area COL insanity is on the verge of making it not worth it. (Washington competitors looking more attractive)

review_title: Awesome Place to Grow and Gain!
pros: Friendly, transparent and honest company to grow with and to gain tons of experience.   You'll come out a very confident and content person.
cons: Perks are always way higher than Pay. Hiring process can be extra complicated! Growth is completely dependent on merit.

review_title: Brought fresh marketing plan by to a business in decline: Victory Gardens as theme for a garden center.
pros: Working with customers and co-workers. Having a chance to try new things and have have the laughs show up in sales.
cons: Meany well, but not enough to overcome (generational) dysfunctional family ownership, not that I'm any judge. Uneven leadership; kept breaking commitments. Greedy. Ugh.

review_title: Decent place to work for initial retail experience
pros: During holiday season you can get a lot of hours. There's a small discount, 10% or 15%. They work around student schedules.
cons: After holiday season it is really hard to get hours, that's the reason I had to quit and switch to a different job. For the first few months after December it gets slow, and I mean SLOW, I was getting maybe 6 - 9 hours per week.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Google is a great place to work. With respect for individual and culture, you get to work with the brightest minds of the word.
cons: Not much to mention here. Google is a great place to work at. Downside being, you will get spoiled at Google and leaving Google would be tough.

review_title: Great job although your mileage will vary with your manager
pros: Google is one of the better companies to work for. The fierce competition for top engineers means lavish perks and excellent work conditions.
cons: Some manager are simply bad. Obstacles to getting your work done. Fortunately Google limits the damage a bad manager can do to your career.

review_title: Yes, it's a good as you think
pros: Surrounded by hard working, smart, professionals. Fairly flat structure. Excellent work-life balance. Room for growth. Pay is sometimes way above industry standards when bonuses and shares are taken into account. Pay increases considerably year to year for good performance. Of course, all the usual perks we know about.
cons: It's a big company, so naturally there will be red tape to deal with. I sometimes wish I could be nimble.

pros: good pay, good O.T Free food, Car (Rental), Gas, Free Shoes (up to $150 every 6 months) paid travel, reward point build up(gas,hotel,air fair). Make your own hours, work independently.
cons: Horrible Health Benefits (through Adecco), No sick days, No Vacation Days, Long Period away from home (single mans job)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA

cons: Get in the wrong workgroup and you will find plenty of political, arrogant colleagues.

review_title: Good choice for smart people seeking stability

cons: The culture varies greatly from department to department and manager to manager -- it can be hit or miss. Additionally, don't expect to be able to work in a location other than where your team is based-- many departments are becoming more restrictive.

pros: get the startup feel working at a big company with all big company benefits, love it, great management and teammates as an engineer all i could ask for
cons: be wary of working for startups, especially those that have raised venture debt, many friends have worked for startups and laid off and when recession comes it will hurt

job_title: Marketing Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Google considered to be one of the great mostly one of the largest companies around the world  especially in marketing  activities and communication  strategies , i think with my background experience i can  benefit the company in such  fields and achieve great  jop  and creative missions.
cons: Gaining more experience, v.good work environment , global marketing strategies,  matching my career , fair enough salary and finacial privildges coditions.

review_title: Low stress job for competent people

cons: The company is getting huge, which leads to complications. I felt like we were hiring too much, and it was sometimes hard to find meaningful projects to work on.

review_title: Google has a long way to go.....

Free Food
Perks (Massages, Onsite Laundry, Dry Cleaning Service)
Bonus Plan/Compensation
Annual Trips
Flexibility to work from home
Working with some of the smartest people in technology!!

pros: Countless opportunities. Great benefits, play an important role from day one. Ability to change things, work with some of the best in the field.
cons: Things are moving slower. People are feeling the pressure of the economy. Bad balance between work and personal life.

pros: Google is a wonderful place to work. New York office is fantastic and I love my team. I encourage everyone to apply.
cons: The cons of working at Google are that if you are not an engineer, there is not as much flexibility and creativity allowed.

pros: Awesome perks, really smart people, working with huge data, great hacker culture, good free food, get to work with a lot of cool technologies
cons: The company is not very agile and it takes a lot to get features rolled out as soon as possible.

pros: innovative and challenging  - management works for the career development of the employees, compensation packages are good, and best office locations in town
cons: very fast paced environment, loads of projects running simultaneously, product is develped very quickly, sometimes the field sales teams hear about a new feature in the field from a client.

review_title: Google is a great brand to work for, great people, if you dont have aa good manager then it is not good at all
pros: Great brand, great people, great products
cons: It is all about who is your manager, and as Google now loosing great people to facebook they are dont have as agreat people as they used to which creats so much politics that you cant believe.

review_title: My experience was great but I wished I had another manager.
pros: Google provides great perks and benefits to their employees!  You are surrounded by bright and competent people.
cons: If you're not an engineer, there are much fewer career advancement opportunities.  It is really easy to gain weight with all the delicious food.

review_title: fun, intellectual, but turning into a huge company
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: intellectual, interesting things to work on, good pay, respectful colleagues, high prestige, decent work to life balance, managers are technically v. strong.
cons: Not all managers know how to manage humans, search quality is very political, lack of company focus, turning into a hierarchical company.

pros:
+ Highest pay around.
+ Free meals & food, transportation, housing, gym access, car sharing.
+ Access to the brightest minds in the industry.
+ Chance to work on real, production code that will be used while you still work there.
cons: Honestly, I have had nothing but a good experience working here.

review_title: Great people to work with, great benefits
job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA

review_title: Worked in support services as employee (non-engineer)

review_title: It was a good company to build experience and be involved in projects but pay was poor

cons: I found a little bit yuppy , some of the staff are very blue chipped and the inside is not what is portrayed to the public

review_title: A great place to work if you are a workaholic

cons: Long hours, employee evaluation system is based on a bell curve, so even a rockstar team has employees "below expectations".

review_title: The People are what make Google Google
pros:
- You're trusted to solve complex problems with some of the most talented minds 
- Flexible work environment that grows with you
- great resources to assist with continued education and career advancement
cons: The only con I would site is that it's a highly competitive place, which is to be expected at a company full of Type A personalities.

review_title: Lots of benefits and experienced gained.
pros:
Great environment, plenty of colour around the office. Great company culture. No uniform required. Fast paced environment which helps to deliver good challenges.

You also get opportunity to do what you want without too much supervision. This is something great about Google because you won't feel confronting at all.
cons: It is better than being at home. Sometimes I'd consider it too good.

pros: free lunch and snacks are great and the environment is very comfortable and approachable. one of the best places that i have ever worked at.
cons: nothing to complain about, everything about the company was great and ran to perfection. i would suggest everyone give google a good look at them because they are a great company to work for.

review_title: Google is an innovative company to work for
pros: It is simply a privilege working with a company of such stature and influence.  The professionals are bright ambitious and enthusiastic.
cons: The corporate culture highly values 'scrappy' which frequently means that being thorough and laying down long lasting foundations are over looked in the exchange for being fast.

review_title: The perks don't justify the slow-moving bureaucracy, especially in HR
job_title: People Programs Specialist in Mountain View, CA
pros:
- Fun, incredibly intelligent co-workers
- The perks, of course
- Internal mobility to switch within the company
cons:
- Sloooow...doing anything takes two weeks minimum
- Promotion process is byzantine and opaque. Years to get into management
- Big-company atmosphere - don't be fooled by the "entrepreneurial culture". 55,000 employees doesn't allow for that
- Stand-offish management

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great products to sell, great people to work with.  Smart, well rounded.  Team environment.  Good emphasis on career development.
cons: It is a very matrixed organization.  Lots of people have input into a disorienting number of the decisions.  Move much slower than people would think for google.

pros: Great work environment, very  bright minds, unbeatable perks. Good support system for new joiners, very clear career path for full time employees.
cons: Low rate of conversion from Contract to Full Time. Not many other cons, simply the best, friendliest working environment you could come across

job_title: SWE III in New York, NY
pros: Everything you've ever heard about working at Google is true. Benefits are awesome, coworkers are awesome, and your work affects millions of people.
cons: Politics are starting to get in the way of engineering. Since launches are incentivized so heavily in promo process, negative dogfood feedback is often ignored on the way to launch, with few or no consequences.

review_title: excellent training ground w/ many opportunities but a large company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Incredibly talented colleagues, innovative, fast-paced work, high level of transparency, data-driven culture that includes constant rigorous work to improve the culture
cons: its a big company with process that is limited for a company of its size but still exists, tremendous horizontal growth opportunities but growing vertically takes time

review_title: The only place better than Google is your own company. Before you have one, Google is the best company to work for.

Very Very smart people. 
Lots to learn.
People are nice.
Nice perks.
Good work life balance (relative to other tech company)

pros: Great company to work for, they look after you and you are surrounded by super smart entrepreneurial people.

review_title: Great company. Incredible people. Challenging projects.

* competitive compensation
* lots of learning opportunities

cons: Google is a commercial company which means you have to do the job required for it to earn money or attract users. Sometime that may not be your most favourite research topic or the cleanest most beautiful code, which may be hard to accept if you are a perfectionist.

review_title: Great company to work for but not without it's flaws.
pros: Great perks, autonomy and smart people to work with. Nice modern offices and new equipment to work with.
cons: If you aren't loved by managers you wont get promoted. Will set higher expectations if they do not like you to avoid giving you promo.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Peters, MO
pros: None that I can think of
cons: Total disrespect for employees, lying.

review_title: A great company to work for!
job_title: LCS Sales Manager in Dublin, Dublin
pros: The pool of talents you'll be working with will stimulate you every day.  The company takes care of its employees, but aside from mere benefits the people around you will really make the difference.
cons: Work and life balance especially in Dublin can be challenging. due to restrictions on working from home, from remote or from other offices.

pros: Google focuses a lot on inclusive culture, to make sure (or try to make sure) people of different gender, race, etc are treated equally. Also Google has a strong focus on people growth, with a lot of open resources, which is a good place to start the career.
cons: The promotion system is generally slow. Since there are so many teams, one may need to work hard to find a real problem to solve.

review_title: Great place to learn, meet excellent people and focus on your personal growth.
pros:
- Google is leading the world's digital transformation and the company makes you feel part of it. 
- Excellent people
- Personal focus, respects work/life balance
- Great compensation with lots of benefits (food, stock...)
cons:
- Google-centricity in your job. Everything you deal with is going to be Google-related, might miss what's happening in the broader ecosystem. 
- Fast-paced, which translates into frequent re-orgs.

job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great perks like free food, manageable hours.
cons:
Sheer number of politics that goes on - some people have been around very long, are insucure, and therefor protective and tertritorial. Not good for innovation or moving the needle forward. 

Also, hard to transfer job ladders if you want to go for example Program Manager to Product. It's all about the internal interviews which are just as hard as external.

review_title: not a very good place to work
pros: i worked as a temp position for google and the only good thing was that the hours were consistent and the pay was decent.
cons: the hours were really inflexible and sometimes it was hard to get time off. the working conditions weren't very ideal either.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Good money, smart people, free food
cons: Death by Powerpoint, somewhat slow moving. As the company has been on a crest of a wave it feels sometimes that there is not really much point to the work. The best things about the company are also the worst things about it, in that there is a lot of waste of time and money.

pros: Smart people.  Being on the cutting edge of the action in Silicon Valley.  An ambitious company.
cons: Becoming more bureaucratic as it grows larger.  Cost cutting really seems to be targeted at the "little people", rather than execs who still seem to do what they want.

review_title: Long hours, great perks, great people
pros: Great people, great perks. The work is interesting, and there can be a great 'if it is broke, go fix it' atmosphere.
cons: Long hours, I work with a team overseas - and so my days can sometimes go from 5AM to 6-7, maybe 8 PM.  It takes a long time to be promoted, due to having great people around you.

job_title: Mechanical Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Great perks, great people, and really challenging problems to work on.  There's a work hard, play hard mentality that makes for a very satisfying career.
cons: Some people don't have a life outside of work and have similar expectations of those around them.  Management works to avoid bureaucracy, but as the company grows it's hard to avoid.  The rapid pace of hiring has definitely changed the feel of the company.

review_title: Great experience but like everywhere else.
pros: Excellent benefits ticks all the boxes and some,, forward-thinking, nice people overall, opportunities to learn about numerous products;
cons: unclear paths to advancement; Goals not always articulated; numerous different managers a different one every 6 months; can feel "cultish" though it would classify as a nice cult

job_title: Engineering Manager in New York, NY
pros:
The people here are smart and, for the most part, not arrogant about it.
You work on code that a good proportion of the world uses and benefits from.
Your computing resources are amazing.
The scope of what Google works on is huge, and mobility between projects is pretty easy.
Work-life balance is great.
Management is technically savvy and treats their staff with proper care and concern.
cons: You won't have a WhatsApp level payout day.

review_title: Fantastic environment, great people, great pay!
pros: People are very smart and nice, environment is like a college - promoting learning through work, and the salary is very competitive.
cons: Sometimes I get too wrapped up in my work and neglect other duties, such as going home, but the college-like atmosphere is really great for allowing you to focus on your project and get work done!

pros: The diversity of opportunity. Google touches so many industries from ad-tech to consumer software and hardware. There is something for everyone at Google and it's very easy to find a role on a product that you truly care about. The culture is incredible and work-life balance is great.
cons: If you live in SF and work in MTV the commute is long. Otherwise there are very few cons to working at Google. They've created an incredible corporate environment.

job_title: Account Executive in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Amazing perks all around
Opportunity to work with some of the best and brightest
Knowing your company impacts millions of people every day
cons:
Size of company means less opportunity for autonomy. I felt like just another cog in the machine towards the end
Calibrations punish some good employees unfairly

review_title: Best big company to work for
pros: Outstanding peers. Everyone is the best person you've ever worked with in that field.
cons: Massive company with an increasing amount of bureaucracy. Really difficult do accomplish anything unless you're good at navigating a big company.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Performance review system -- it is objectively unbiased and fair.
Hiring -- its impartial -- only good hires make it in.
Food -- Matters more than you think. 
Peers -- Are interesting and good.
Internal mobility -- Can and do change teams on an appropriate basis.
cons: Reorgs -- Can get rearranged and moved around.

pros: Amazing, friendly, super helpful people. All highly intelligent but don't hold it over anyone's heads. Fantastic offices that aide in making every day at work a pleasure (but still promoting healthy work-life balance!)
cons: The only con that I can think of is that I'm only an intern-- can't wait for the opportunity to become a full timer!

pros: really good job, super smart people, great culture, lots of learning, room for growth, would definitely go back in a more senior role
cons: a bit stifled as far as involvement for lower level employees, would like to have more opportunities to contribute strategically and on different projects

job_title: Decision Support Analyst in Mountain View, CA
pros:
1. The job is challenging and you get to learn.
2. Your teammates and colleague are generally very very smart and relatively nice.
cons:
1. Promotion is hard. It depends on not only your performance, but also how your team's status, and some relatively random decision.
2. It's a very demanding job. You have really high peer pressure if you want to stand out.

pros: Great coworkers, detailed docs and a lot of learning materials to help you become a good engineer.
cons:
1. There is not so much work to do.
2. food is not good
3. life is just too at ease, no challenge.

review_title: A Sense of Being Part of Something Big
pros: Seemingly unlimited resources; work with top/diverse talent from across the globe; amazing perks from food to testing of prototype consumer technologies.
cons: Extremely competitive; take home pay is not as high as non-Googlers assume it is; many poorly socialized individuals around.

pros: It is abosolutely an amazing place to grow and learn. People are fine and all the free food is greate
cons: It just has so many talented people so the space for you is very limited. And one can feel pressure at there.

pros: Google is very wide spread and offers interesting problems in many areas. Google has great pay and excellent benefits.
cons: As a big company Google has lots of politics. It has become  hierarchical and there is lots overhead like meetings. The 20% time is touted but not that real in practice.

review_title: Fast, Innovative, Challenging. What you need.
pros: It is easy to roll  eyes when people from Facebook say how open their culture is, but it's true; it's more open than any other place I've worked at. In such a great company, secret projects, public incidents, important non-public business metrics and the like are all openly discussed.
cons: It is very hard to make a difference. Also it is really hard to follow the pace at first.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Free great food, surrounded by genius people, incredible working atmosphere, great for internship and for full time job, and it's GOOGLE!
cons: There are not much to say about  cons of working at Google, but if i Had to choose one, it would be the pressure to finish all the work.

pros: Not a secret but Google continues to be one of the best places to work at. You will work with the world's best and have freedom to reach your full potential.
cons: Not a real cons but you can get disoriented by the amount of stuff happening around you. Also, the talent around you can be almost intimidating but the best talent thrives in that environment

review_title: Great perks, interesting work, totally insulated from outside
job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros:
- Compensation and perks are great
- Company values align with my own (engineering excellence, improving the world, etc)
- Extremely flexible work, both in schedule and picking what you work on
- Interesting work
cons:
- Insulated from the outside world (both the campus and software/tools used)
- Hard to figure out what to work on (downside of extreme flexibility)

review_title: Great place to work, dynamic and creative
pros:
great benefits
great projects
ability to deliver/launch projects within a short time frame
collaborative/fast faced working athmosphere
cons:
sometimes things happen so fast, managers easily loose focus on long term vision and prioritise short-term tactical deliveries
company is more vertical than they'd claim, still hierarchical and decisions sometimes take a long time to get approved

pros: Good salary and benefits.  Google has an unwritten ethos to make the world a better place - not just "Don't be evil" - and that feeling is shared by most employees, who will complain to management if they feel that isn't happening in the context of some new decision.
cons: Getting large, so it's hard to make a big positive impact

pros: Provides with good environment and working area.  Because employers in India are in need of good environment to enjoy there  working profession.
cons: Can't really share about this topic because working in such environment provides with good thoughts. Working with enjoyment gives work an another level.

pros:
I came for "two years". I'm at Google over seven and counting. 

Great peers with a culture that fosters collaboration and learning from others. 

Lots of flexibility - working hours, working from home, team and product mobility. 

Competitive perks, benefits and compensation.
cons: As the company grows there is more bureaucracy and formality, but still not as much for a company this size

review_title: Great change in pace and maturity
pros: Everybody talks about the great perks and benefits but I love how you get freedom to create and make an impact here with great management
cons: In short, old company was drchrono in Sunnyvale and the managers were v unprofessional with a ton of micromanagement, long hours and low pay.

review_title: Great role for sales career, Think again for marketing career
pros: Good Pay, Flexible work depending on team, Good international experience, possibility to move offices.
cons: Hard to find work in marketing after it as it's super specialised in Google products. Easy to find sales and account management roles though, so I would advise the role for someone looking to build a tech sales career, not for anyone trying to build a career in Marketing.

pros: Innovative, curious, empathic people make it a great environment to grow, learn and develop ideas and oneself.
cons: Working load if not managed well can get excessive. That said no one forces you, but as you are surrounded by ambitious, smart individuals the bar is high and so to excel many push themselves beyond a healthy worklife balance.

job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
Great Perks

Great Pay

job_title: Site Reliability Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Apart from the perks and benefits what it gives you is shaping your mindset and in turn yourself in a very positive way! A company which can think beyond itself, A company which values their employee, A company which shapes how engineers should be, A company which sets the golden standard for how the business should be, in nutshell A company with great foundation!!
cons: There is nothing I can think of.

review_title: Amazing experience - yes Google is that cool!!!
job_title: Technical Recruiter in Mountain View, CA
pros: Smart people, extremely diverse culture, open environment for creativity... a model for a lot of companies. Technically very advanced - start of the art equipment and the best social activities that make you proud to be there.
cons: It's a monster, flat organization doesn't allow for much advancement.

job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Mountain View, CA
pros: It is the best place for software engineers. You can lean a lot from smart googlers. Also, meals are free.
cons: MTV is in California, which means higher tax rate, higher living cost, etc. However, you may make more money in google than other companies.

review_title: Pretty much all that I could ask for in a job
pros:
Lots of freedom to work on projects and ideas of your own choosing.
World changing projects - help improve products for millions of people.
Great compensation packages
cons: Google might not be the right place for you if you don't know how to navigate ambiguity and get things done with minimal oversight. Need to be able to influence across functions.

pros: I would say that the quality of my co-workers is very high.  My managers have all at least seemed to be concerned with my personal well-being.  There is always something new to learn here.
cons: Quarter performance evaluations can be a little wearing.  Good communication with the technical leadership on your project is a must for success a Google.

review_title: If you're an engineer, it's pretty sweet.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: Excellent salary / benefits / perks. Super smart people. Challenging projects. You learn a TON working here.
cons: If you're in a remote office (outside MTV), it can be hard to make lateral moves in your career.

review_title: If you thought Google was good, it's better than that.
pros: Best food ever, friendly and intelligent colleagues who could become close friends, Beautiful office, cabs to pick you up and drop you, opportunity to apply for IJPs often.
cons: Monotonous work initially. Very little learning from the initial work. You need to get a new role before you can start learning more.

pros:
You get to work with cool innovative products, in a great environment (especially in terms of positive, friendly and skilled colleagues). The brand is well known.
You have a lot of freedom in customer interaction and in planning your projects.
cons:
There are not many opportunities for technical roles in this office, but this depends on specific offices.
The base salary is not exciting, compared to other offers you can get from competitors.

pros: You can work with probably the best colleagues in the world, work hard and learn a lot. Also the food is a big advantage than other small companies.

review_title: Expect to work like donkey or you will be kicked out
job_title: Software Engineer III in Mountain View, CA
pros:
1. Free food, this is the best part in Google. 
2. Talented people around you, and you will learn in day to day activities.
cons:
1. Long working hours, no work-life balance. 
2. If you work only for 40hours, you won't get promoted and you will be sacked.

job_title: Legal Assistant in Mountain View, CA
pros: Coworkers are incredibly smart and driven.  Abundant resources are available to get accomplish your goals.  Amazing perks.  Great mission.
cons: Working in the legal department without a JD creates a glass ceiling in upward mobility (as can be expected from working in any legal environment without a JD)

review_title: All glam, just a cog in another corporate wheel
pros: Great food, smart people, and a healthy work-life balance. Did I mention that the food is really great? Because it is.
cons: Super hierarchical structure, not a meritocracy. At the end of the day, you're just a cog in a big money-making machine, so your work will be not that interesting. There's a ton of bureaucracy to deal with as well.

pros: Despite it's size, Google continues to innovate, treat it's employees well, and have tough problems to solve. You can't go wrong by getting a job here. There are so many teams that if you don't find the perfect fit at first, just keep looking (which is easy!) and you'll probably find something to enjoy.
cons: You won't work at the speed of a startup, even if you join a small team.

pros: Great salary and benefits and resources. The amount of intelligent people working for this company can be a bit overwhelming and forces you to be the best.
cons: Hard to find free time outside of work. My family started to become distant and I came to the realization that I needed to spend more time with them. Hopefully Google will offer more work from home and vacation opportunities.

pros: Very cool people and offices. If you like to work for an innovative company: this is the best company to work for.
cons: As tour teammates are also very clever, the challenge is to show ypur results in order to Get a promotion.

pros: It's a good company for new grads - there's plenty of opportunities to learn, and it's especially great if you don't know what area you want to work in, so many teams are always hiring
cons: You enter into the company not knowing which team you will be working with, and then have to interview with TLs.  Some people may like it, but it's an extra level of bureaucracy I didn't enjoy.

pros: Free food, nice work environment and nice salary. And lots of opportunity to be exposed to new technology. And everyone is friendly

review_title: No career path but great perks!
job_title: Senior Account Executive in New York, NY
pros: Great perks such as parental leave, PTO policy, 401(k) match and on-site restaurants. Base pay can also be attractive.
cons: No career path. Horrible work life balance. Need to work night and day to get promoted. Change manager too often to learn anything. Project changes too often to  see any personal impact.

review_title: Be sure to read through previous reviews
pros: Get to choose your own hours
cons:
There's no benefit to being able to "choose your own hours" if you have to base your hours around when clients are available.  I find myself waiting for users to show up, which is not only a waste of my time, it definitely restricts my time flexibility which is the whole benefit of taking on this role.

I urge anyone considering this company to read through the previous reviews regarding the bait and switch, how they move you to an empty queue (no users to help) if you make a decent amount of money (and that amount is not disclosed, and they don't notify you that they are moving you), and how the "management"  is not willing to communicate how anyone's pay is calculated.  

It has been an extremely disheartening and frustrating experience, and I cannot begin to express how disappointed I am that Google attaches itself to this app.  As the parent company, Google really should step in and do something.

And to the employee who commented that the issues involving pay and pay changes are borderline illegal...I can't disagree and wish someone had the ability to spark a change so that it's a better working environment which would then lend to a better user experience, and then make the app and company more successful.

pros: Free breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Google is not a conventional company, and we don’t intend to become one. True, we share attributes with the world’s most successful organizations – a focus on innovation and smart business practices comes to mind – but even as we continue to grow, we’re committed to retaining a small-company feel. At Google, we know that every employee has something important to say, and that every employee is integral to our success. We provide individually-tailored compensation packages that can be comprised of competitive salary, bonus, and equity components, along with the opportunity to earn further financial bonuses and rewards.
cons:
Google has offices around the globe, from Bangalore to Zurich, but regardless of where we are, we nurture an invigorating, positive environment by hiring talented, local people who share our commitment to creating search perfection and want to have a great time doing it. Googlers thrive in small, focused teams and high-energy environments, believe in the ability of technology to change the world, and are as passionate about their lives as they are about their work.
Lend a helping hand. With millions of visitors every month, Google has become an essential part of everyday life - like a good friend - connecting people with the information they need to live great lives.
 Life is beautiful. Being a part of something that matters and working on products in which you can believe is remarkably fulfilling.
Appreciation is the best motivation, so we’ve created a fun and inspiring workspace you’ll be glad to be a part of, including on-site doctor and dentist; massage and yoga; professional development opportunities; shoreline running trails; and plenty of snacks to get you through the day.
Work and play are not mutually exclusive. It is possible to code and pass the puck at the same time

review_title: Internal mobility is difficult in some departments.
pros: Development tools are perfect. Engineering Excellence is peak and you'll improve your coding skills significantly.
cons: Be aware that internal mobility between ladders/locations are very difficult in some departments where internal recruiting is low. CorpEng (Corporate Engineering Department) is one of the top department that is applying this policy since management is only interested in their own benefits. Even you agree with some manager for mobility in other departments, they'll try to interrupt the process. They don't look at employee's career/family perspective. Be aware about department you're joining after interviews.

review_title: Looks like a dream company but it's not always the case

cons: Lots of underperforming long time employees and managers aren't courageous enough to fire them.

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for, including my own company
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros:
The engineers here are the best I've ever worked with, hands down.
The company promotes the right people and fires the right people.
The pay, benefits, and perks are amazing.
The people really care for each other and look out for one another.
Work life balance is great.
cons: No real cons come to mind.

review_title: The best experience in my carreer
job_title: Site Reliability Engineer in London, England
pros:
Great projects and culture, plenty of nice and interesting people to work with, easy to get involved in whatever interests you.
Also plenty of resources and supportive management which allows to be ambitious and still succeed.
Perks are also great.
cons: I can't imagine working somewhere else even for much more money.

job_title: Product Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros: Amazing culture, free food, smart people, interesting projects, all this while having a huge impact
cons: It is getting a big company - so politics is creeping in, a lot of slack in pockets.

review_title: The People Make this Place Great!
pros: Incredible company full of smart, motivated employees.  I've rarely encountered disgruntled employees grumbling to each other at the water cooler.  Everyone is passionate about their personal hobbies and brings their A game to work every day.
cons: It's a flat organization, which means it's difficult to get promoted or get a fancy title.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Employees and company values are great. Colleagues cheer you on and are very supportive of one another even though there is a lot of competition. People are willing to jump in to get things done. It is relatively easy to jump between groups/orgs.
cons: Work-life balance can be difficult. Google makes it really easy to stay after hours.

review_title: I am greatly enjoying what I do.
job_title: Software Engineer III in Mountain View, CA
pros: The culture. Specifically, the way my coworkers treat me, the way my manager treats me, the policies that affect me, the work itself, and the opportunities for growth.
cons: The noise and density of the Mountain View offices. I'm introverted, and I have to use earplugs or work from home to work effectively.

job_title: Group Product Marketing Manager in Mountain View, CA

cons: Work-life balance can be tough. As big as the company is, there are some extra-lean teams taking a lot on. Also need better gender balance in the workforce.

pros: Great perks, team and work environment.  The company is very transparent and gives lots of freedom for the employees to pursue their interests.

pros: It is great to work with smart coworkers. It saves a lot of time in making things clear. Most of the time communication is efficient, expect when there is conflicts among senior leaders.
cons: It is become bigger and layered. Most of the time you don't know which part you are working on within the huge system.

pros: Very smart people and flexibility to choose your projects, to choose your research areas. Overall I think my coworkers are extremely well qualified for their job.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Pittsburgh, PA

* Great benefits and perks.
* You can switch projects every few years.
* You get to work on Important projects.

review_title: My experience at work was economically very good

pros:
Really value people for their achievements, they took the risk many Tech companies do not want to take : trained agency Recruiters from the ground up and got me where I am today. 
Very grateful, extremely pleasant experience.

pros: Google attracts and keeps talents with its competitive salaries.Apparently, working at Google is the best part about working at Google. Makes sense.

pros:

job_title: Sales Director in New York, NY

Perks are legendary
Compensation is rich
We hire phenomenal people
Impressive (continued) growth
Incredible brand name - excellent place to start your career

Limited career advancement for managers and above

 Poor VP direction and management

pros: Excellent culture, benefits, company as a whole. A lot of companies care either about their users or their employees. Google cares a lot about both.

review_title: Great effort to support under-represented group to thrive in the company
